Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: good
6hr/week
4 hours
1-2 hours/week (except during the week of our presentation, then closer to 4-5 hours/week)
good

strengths - instructor was fantastic
weaknesses - too much innovation focused on entrepreneurship.  I would have liked to see more innovation within hospital systems or related to government policy choices

Strengths: interesting topics, very experienced professor, workload is fair
Weaknesses: learning expectations not always clear, expectations not balanced between students with very different levels of healthcare industry experience (ex. should encourage non-MD/MBA students to feel qualified to speak up)

Great! I learned so much about new ventures and ways of thinking in public health. The team did a great job of picking cases and curating the syllabus to provide insight into what can be a crowded market with new ventures happening in various field.
Overall, great topics and cases presented in the course. Lectures/discussions could have been more structured.
Great Class. Very much enjoyed the perspective from the prof and other students.
Great class, great professor, should not be a capstone for HCM if other MBAs with minimal healthcare experience are in it.

The class does not need to be 3 hours, especially in the evening with no food provided. While there was a lot of good information in these sessions, it always ran over by a minimum of 15 minutes. It also would get off topic and the professor would expect answers that weren't covered in the class preparation materials.
Poor facilitation of discussions, excessive amounts of repetitive readings, and not challenging enough to actually critically analyze or study anything interesting
strengths: a broad range of topics covered by this module. highly encouraging environment to speak up in class.

I was very much looking forward to this course, but was overall left extremely disappointed and annoyed. I hate to say this because all my experiences and courses at SOM have been nothing but positive, btu this was easily the worst class I took while at SOM. It is unfortunate this is considered our capstone and a 'culmination' of all we have learned. The strengths were that the case studies could actually be interesting, but weaknesses were the professor, lack of structure or any key takeaway points during discussion. There were one or two interesting guest speakers, but some also got carried away and did not offer helpful takeaways.

- too much emphasis on class participation and discussion. This motivated students just to speak for the sake of getting participation points and also skewed the grading in the favor of those who did that. Not every student is very talkative or comfortable speaking repeatedly in such a large classroom setting. The grading was completely fair as the final course grades were heavily weighed on this one portion of the class
- the grading for the presentation was also unfair and harsh. It also favored those who were free and able to present earlier, by giving them bonus points that truly give them too much of an edge and skewed the average grade. 
- there were never any comments on the written assignments. I received a 2.5 or 2 out of three on majority of assignments with no feedback and thus, I had no way to improve or understand the nature of my grade. Even though I was doing above average on the assignments, my grade reflected participation much more heavily.

The readings were very interesting but they were lengthy and the case write-up was a way of synthesizing all of that information. Overall, the discussion was thought-provoking but I do think there was too much emphasis on asking us open-ended questions rather than sharing actual facts/industry trends. If the time of this class changed from 4-7 to 1-4 that would be amazing

interesting course that focuses on a variety of innovation examples for health care (not just the expected "tech" innovations)
really cool to have the founders/leaders of the companies studied sit in on class with us to hear our input regarding the case study and answer our questions personally.

Strengths: learning about new innovation in the healthcare space

Weaknesses: a little too much class conversation- appreciated that everyone spoke, but it came to a point that people were speaking just for the sake of getting the participation points.

My favourite course at Yale so far. It effectively combine so many different concepts in healthcare strategy, innovation, economics and finances, to think critically about the future. I enjoyed the discussions in each class session and the professor does an exceptional job of leading the discussion in a methodical manner. I would take this course every year if I could.

Improvements - a session on international innovations; there is much to be learned from other countries too

Excellent course.  Excellent topics.  I would like to see more stuff on operations of a hospital, but it only a soft suggestion. 

However, I would recommend that having a pre-conference call with the presenters is very important.  Some of the presenters were asked very pointed questions, and they were not ready to answer them candidly.  So its important for the presenters to be ready to be candid with the audience, if they try to hide behind something else it shows through in their presentation,
great

AP MPH Student R/V 

The title of the course is "Sustainable Innovation in HC" - yet one of the guest speakers were from the company Proteus, which markets their version of an anti-psychotic Aripiprazole that normally costs less than $20, for $1600 A MONTH. They have a patch that goes across the stomach and a digital sensor in the pill that allows for drug compliance to be tracked. Innovative? Sure yes. Useful? Maybe. Sustainable? Hard no. The course repeatedly talks about the problem of rising costs in US healthcare, yet we're presented with stuff like this in class?

Have absolutely no idea how this was marked as a Capstone course for the health policy MPH track when there was virtually no discussion about policy. It's a supposed to be a joint course, but was so business orientated. Class participation for credit also highly irritating and just forced people to say stuff for the sake of saying it to get. Getting rid of this will actually facilitate genuine discussion. 

Class ran late every single time despite being 3 hours long!!

- Unorganized canvas - it takes a long time to comb through all the files to see which ones are required readings
- Artificially extending classon a Monday night please let students leave at 7, it has been a long day
- Professor has a really soothing voice, which can unintentionally put you to sleep on Monday night
- Presentations are supposed to take 25 min.. consistently take up 40+ mins each 
- MBA/MPH students arent the same as eMBA. We are much younger but also have existing content knowledge re: PBMs, basic healthcare things

The course content was fine, but there was a large gap in the understanding of those in the room. It felt like a lot of our class time was spent reviewing things that everyone knew and understood and it was dumbed down too much. However, the subject matter and speakers that came in were both very interesting
Great survey of healthcare topics as they relate to business-related principles - would highly recommend to MBA students interested in learning more about healthcare sectors in greater detail.
Went through a lot of very basic concepts that as second years we knew already

Strengths - great guest speakers

Weaknesses - classroom dialogue is not well-facilitated and comments did not build on each other/people weren't redirected if they were going on a tangent; wish there was more time for guest speakers (or that they were put at the beginning and then allowed to leave); student presentations did not relate to the content of class

Strengths: great speakers
Weaknesses: not a strong enough focus on sustainability
It was interesting but should been a full semester.

Strengths: discussion of important topics not often discussed in healthcare; company case studies were excellent

Weaknesses: Class discussion was often hard to follow

Topics were interesting, timely, and relevant but professor patronized us and we wanted more time interacting with the industry guests. Dont think the professor did a good job of facilitating conversation
good
He is extremely knowledgeable, well connected, and gifted at facilitating student discussions.

Strengths: Professor Licholai is brilliant and very experienced in the business of healthcare, so he is an invaluable connection to have and to learn from. He chose topics that are highly relevant to students going into healthcare next year.
Weaknesses: Lectures can be a bit disorganized/not always sure of the main takeaways.
Fantastic! I appreciated his insights from his career and the way he moderated the discussion and guest speakers.

Prof Licholai is very knowledgable and passionate about the content of the course. However, some discussions and presentation Q&A's seemed to have digressed greatly from the main point of the student group presentations, causing the class to go significantly over time. Would be great to follow what was stated in the syllabus, instead of having some project groups present and answer class questions for an hour, while others presented for the expected 20 mins. Doesn't seem fair for some groups to answer questions for 40 minutes while other groups only had to answer questions for 10 minutes and still be graded on the same scale.
Phenomenal Instructor
Great professor, awesome at leading discussions and fostering a positive learning environment.
Brilliant, but needs to do a better job of keeping time, and understanding the level of knowledge and experience in the room.
Disrespectful of students' time (consistently went past class time) and hard to pay attention to.
guide the conversation in class and drive critical thinking

he professor should be a wealth of knowledge, but instead leaves it to students to open vague and open-ended opinions to drive the entire 3 hour session. I understand his intent is to try and engage students which I appreciate, but the fact that one obscure comment drives the entire discussion and he does not offer any pedagogy to direct or lead the class towards to a key takeaway was nothing less than frustrating.

- We need more insight from you and less from classmates. It's great to get opinions and hear about the vast experience of those in the classroom, but this cannot be used to guide the entire class. It is completely reflective of who says what in the class that day and there is no structured key-takeaways. 
- The speakers often handled Q&A inappropriately and came off as them defending their product/service. ESP the mental health app speakers

Professor Licholai was kind, engaging, and easy to talk to. He wanted everyone to be involved which I appreciated. I do think he didn't really teach that much and wanted us to just candidly debate with each other and talk about our opinions. It was more of a seminar which wasn't what I was expecting given how large the class size was.

Quite good. I wish there had been a bit more true teaching rather than just rhetorical or re-stating questions for class discussion. At a certain point, Dr. Licholai is an accomplished leader in healthcare, we all want to hear what he has to say rather than 3 hours of opinions from fellow students.

Should have been taught at a higher level. 
Professor did not respect student's time. Went way over almost every single class.
Best person to teach this course - he can effectively combine so many different facets of the healthcare industry
Excellent
great

Very nice individual. Clearly very successful. Created a friendly atmosphere in class. Annoying that he kept saying that "we're all MBA students here" when this is supposed to be a joint course with YSPH and a capstone for the policy track - yet the Professor doesn't even have an idea of who is in the class.
He's personally very interesting but I think needed to get a better feel for the audience

Wish he contributed more of his own opinions and insights in response to students questions, instead of presenting more questions - discussion threads became very difficult to follow as he tried to elicit certain responses and students became confused. Also didnt help that he kept our group in front of the class for 45 minutes when the expectation was 10 minutes for group presentations - his standards felt very inconsistent across the board and based on his personal preferences.
Professor LIcholai is great, very friendly and knowledgeable

Professor Licholai is clearly knowledgeable in the subject matter and extremely well-connected, as evident by the guest speakers he is able to bring.  His teaching could be improved by more intentionally driving the classroom dialogue and pushing back on ideas that may not be useful.

Strengths: engages students
Weakness: instruction is not timed to match class length
His version of the Socratic method was not helpful.

Topics were interesting, timely, and relevant but professor patronized us and we wanted more time interacting with the industry guests. Dont think the professor did a good job of facilitating conversation
good

This course is a fantastic introduction to sustainable innovations.  You will give a presentation, which is quite a bit of work.  You will prepare reading summaries each week for a grade.  Participation is necessary.  Preparation is necessary too.
I would recommend this course to students with an interest in healthcare who need an extra elective. However, this is not a class that will teach you tons more that you do not already know.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in how business and public health intersect.
Overall, take the course if you're passionate about healthcare innovation.
Highly recommend
Certainly worth taking

Probably one of the worst courses I've taken at Yale (or maybe in my life). If you have a strong background in healthcare, this class might be too basic for you. If you do not have a strong background in healthcare and are wanting to learn more about innovations within the field, the class might introduce you to some interesting topics. 

Class had the potential to cover some really interesting topics, but the execution was extremely poor. The lectures and teaching style did not encourage students to think critically about any of the topics, and class discussions were not managed well.

But overall, would not recommend. Your time is better spent on pretty much any other course at SOM.
this module is great for people not familiar with business concepts in Life Sciences industry.

I would say it's unfortunate you have to take this course as your capstone, but just grin and bear it. The questions you will be asked are not meaningful or insightful that you will likely not want to participate. However, for purposes of participation you can try and answer some basic questions (often the professor will ask the same things again and again).

- terrible capstone class. Felt like a really bad way to wrap up my coursework 
- going over much too basic of information which really discouraged me from participating further (I was already wary because the whole class depended on participation/people wanting to get participation points) --> No real lecture/insight from the professor
- we needed more tangible strategies/information that we can take with us in the future. I thought this class was simply an open forum for people to exchange ideas that were regurgitated over and over again.
Still the content material is fascinating and relevant. I loved how there was a professional speaker or CEO every week to share their experiences.
A very good introduction to learning about innovative companies in healthcare. If you're not interested in healthcare, this class is not for you.
Great course to take during your last semester (after completing all the core courses in HCM)
Very good
great
Some good speakers. Overall it was decent, just would prefer some kind of public health/policy lens on it if it's going to be advertised as a joint course.
A good overview of various areas within the healthcare system but a long class period that often lent itself to boring/circular conversations

Again, great for MBAs who want to gain a deeper understanding of life sciences and start-up industries within healthcare that intersect more explicitly with business principles. Not sure I would recommend to MPH students.
It is a good course, but a bit boring at times

This course is a smattering of topics across the healthcare innovation space.  Each class lives as its own independent topic with guest speakers relevant to the topic.  At the end of each lecture, there will be student presentations on healthcare companies that are likely not to relate to the topic of lecture (so be prepared for somewhat of a disconnect between lecture and presentations).
Discussion of innovative companies within various healthcare sectors and the ways in which they differentiate themselves from competitors.
Yes I would recommend.
Do not take if Greg is teaching it. Otherwise its an interesting class with good content
